controllers.simple_text.tips_top.title: Tips
controllers.simple_text.tips.category1.t: Sync Pairs
On Pasio, a sync pair is the term given to the combination of one Trainer and one Pokémon. Pokémon battles on Pasio comprise multiple sync-pair teams.
Stats

Numbers are used to express a sync pair’s strength. There are six stat categories, and their numbers affect the outcome of battles.
HP Represents how much energy the sync pair has. When this number reaches zero, the sync pair will faint.
Attack Represents the sync pair’s physical attack power. The higher the number, the more physical damage the sync pair deals to an opponent with physical moves.
Defense Represents the sync pair’s defense against physical moves. The higher the number, the less damage the sync pair takes from physical moves.
Sp. Atk Represents the power of the sync pair’s special attacks. The higher the number the more damage the sync pair deals with special moves.
Sp. Def Represents the sync pair’s defense against special attacks. The higher the number, the less damage the sync pair takes from special moves.
Speed Represents the sync pair’s speed. The higher the number, the faster the move gauge fills, allowing the sync pair to use moves more quickly.
Roles

Roles indicate what each sync pair excels at in battle. There are three kinds of roles.
Strike These sync pairs excel at attacking their opponent. Despite their high Attack and Sp. Atk levels, most sync pairs have low HP, making them vulnerable defensively.
Tech These sync pairs excel at hindering their opponents by inflicting them with status conditions and weakening them.
Support These sync pairs excel at assisting their allies by healing and upgrading them. Most also have a lot of HP, making them adept at withstanding attacks from opponents.
★s
A sync pair’s initial level cap varies according to the number of ★s on its icon.
Level (Lv.)

Sync pairs use the experience they earn in battle to increase their level, resulting in improved stats and even obtaining area information relating to Pokémon Evolution for some pairs.
Once a sync pair reaches its level cap, it cannot level up any further.
Pokémon Types
There are 18 types in total: Normal, Fire, Water, Electric, Grass, Ice, Fighting, Poison, Ground, Flying, Psychic, Bug, Rock, Ghost, Dragon, Dark, Steel, and Fairy.
Passive Skills

Sync pairs can have passive skills, which have an effect on battles. You can view the effects of passive skills by going to Edit Team via the Team menu, selecting a sync pair, and then checking under Passive Skill on its profile to get more info.

Weaknesses &
Supereffective Moves

Some regular moves and sync moves have types. In addition, sync pairs have a single type weakness. If you perform a move that is your opponents’ type weakness, it will be super effective and deal more damage. Similarly, if your sync pair is struck by a move type that it is weak to, they will take more damage.
Critical Hits

During battle, some attacks may deal more damage than usual. These are known as critical hits. Supereffective attacks can also land as critical hits. When you land a critical hit in a co-op battle, the unity gauge fills more quickly.
Gear

Giving gear to a team can strengthen its sync pairs. The effects of gear extend to all of the team’s sync pairs. Some gear is only for designated sync pairs. In that case, its effects will be halved for sync pairs on the team who don’t fulfill its conditions.
Favorite Sync Pairs
You can set a sync pair as your favorite via your Profile in the Poryphone menu. Sync pairs you have favorited can also be seen by your friends.
controllers.simple_text.tips.category2.t: Use level-up manuals to increase a sync pair’s experience.
Raise a sync pair’s level cap with specific items.

Power-Up: Use this item on a sync pair to raise their stats. You can find it in the Team menu under Increase Potential.
The number of times power-ups can be used depends on the sync pair’s number of ★s. Using the most power-ups possible for a sync pair increases its number of ★s. Once the sync pair’s number of ★s reaches its maximum level, it will no longer increase.
Some power-ups have an expiration date and will disappear if you do not use them in time.
When you acquire a duplicate sync pair, the level of its sync move increases. Sync moves have a maximum level of 5, and their damage increases with each rise in level.
From Moves & Skills on the Team menu, your sync pair can learn new moves or passive skills with certain items.
You can upgrade gear by using certain items. Upgrading gear boosts its effects.
Gear can only be upgraded to a certain level. However, you can go over this cap by exchanging duplicate gear.

Some sync pairs acquire Pokémon Evolution area info once they reach a certain level. By exploring these areas, you can evolve your sync pair’s Pokémon, increasing the sync pair’s stats. Once a Pokémon evolves, it cannot return to its previous form. Evolution materials are required to take on Evolution areas. You can exchange items for Evolution materials in the shop.
The move gauge is required to perform moves in battle. You can expand it by advancing through the main story and trading in coins at the shop.
controllers.simple_text.tips.category3.t: Moves
Sync pairs have different moves they can use in battle. Some moves require use of the move gauge. Moves that don’t use the move gauge can only be used a certain number of times.
Move Gauge
During battle, the move gauge fills up over time. Moves that use the move gauge cannot be performed until the move gauge is sufficiently full. Different moves use up a different amount of the gauge.
Moves with a Limited Number of Uses
Some moves can only be used a certain number of times. This number is reset at the end of each area.
Move Types
Some regular moves and sync moves have types. If you perform a move that is the type of your opponents’ weakness, it will be super effective and deal more damage.
Categories

The following is a list of move categories.
Physical The higher the Attack of the sync pair used, the greater the damage its physical attacks deal. Conversely, the higher your opponent’s Defense, the less damage they take.
Special The higher the Sp. Atk of the sync pair used, the greater the damage their special attacks deal. Conversely, the higher your opponent’s Sp. Def, the less damage they take.
Status These moves do not deal damage directly. They include moves that change the target’s stats, inflict status conditions, or heal.
Power
The higher the number, the more damage the move deals to the opponent.
Accuracy
The higher the number, the more likely the move is to hit the opponent.
Target

Indicates a move’s area of effect.
Self Affects only the sync pair that used the move.
Single Opponent Affects a single opponent you select.
All Opponents Affects all opposing sync pairs in the battle.
Single Ally Affects a single ally you select.
All Allies Affects all allied sync pairs in the battle.
Field of play Affects the field of play.
Allied field of play Affects the allied field of play.
Opponents’ field of play Affects the opponents’ field of play.
Sync Moves
Sync moves are attacks that can only be used when the sync move counter reaches zero. The counter decreases by one every time you perform a move.
Special Attacks
Sync moves and unity attacks are special kinds of attacks that can ignore the effects of many moves and passive skills while dealing damage.
controllers.simple_text.tips.category4.t: Sync Pair Stat Changes

A sync pair’s stats can be temporarily altered by move effects and other means.
The sync pair’s stat rank is set at 0, and can decrease 6 points or increase 6 points for a total of 13 ranks. However, a sync pair’s critical-hit rate ranges from 0 to 3.
These stat changes are indicated by icons.
Some moves, passive skills, or sync moves may be affected by these stat changes. However, stat changes that are caused by status conditions do not have such effects.
Changes to stats are reset when the sync pair is switched.
Field Effects

Effects on the field of play affect all sync pairs and can cover three areas: the allied side, the opposing side, and the entire field. Sync pairs in those areas are affected. The following is a list of effects on the field of play. (Some wear out after a period of time.)
Damage Reduction Reduces damage taken by the target. Some effects reduce damage taken from physical moves, and some effects reduce damage from special moves.
Status Move Defense Prevents the opponent’s status moves from affecting the target.
Status Condition Prevention Prevents status conditions from being inflicted on the target. However, moves that inflict status conditions upon the user cannot be defended against.
Status Condition Reflection When a status move would inflict a special condition on the target, that special condition is reflected. However, effects of moves that inflict status conditions upon the user or effects other than status moves that may cause a status condition cannot be reflected.
Stat Reduction Defense Effects that lower stats do not affect the target. However, moves that lower the user’s own stats cannot be defended against.
Stat Reduction Reflection When a status move would reduce the stats of the target, that stat reduction is reflected. However, effects of moves that reduce the user’s own stats or effects other than status moves that may reduce stats cannot be reflected.
Critical-Hit Defense Prevents attacks from being critical hits.
Unity Disruption Makes it difficult for the target’s team to fill their unity gauge.
Chain Reduction Reduces the amount of time chains can continue.
Switch Prevention Prevents sync pairs from switching.
Move Gauge Acceleration Causes the target’s move gauge to fill more quickly.
Weather Change Protection Prevents the weather from being changed.
Status Conditions

Sync pairs can be inflicted with status conditions by moves or other means during battle. The following is a list of status conditions.
Poisoned Lose HP for each action performed.
Badly Poisoned Lose HP for each action performed. The amount of HP lost increases over time.
Paralyzed The Pokémon may not perform a move successfully, but they will not fail to perform a sync move. The sync pair’s speed is also reduced.
Burned Lose HP for each action performed. Also reduces the sync pair’s Attack stat while in effect.
Asleep Makes a sync pair fall asleep, leaving the Pokémon unable to perform moves. They will wake up after a certain amount of time has passed or if they use their sync move. Some moves can still be used while asleep.
Frozen Freezes a sync pair, leaving the Pokémon unable to perform moves. They will thaw out after a certain amount of time has passed or if they use their sync move. Some moves can still be used while frozen.
Status conditions are not removed when a sync pair switches out, but once inflicted with one status condition, a sync pair can’t be inflicted with another. Status conditions are removed when the battle ends or when a move designed to remove status conditions is used. Sync moves can still be used while a sync pair is inflicted with a status condition; using a sync move causes the condition to be removed.
Status Changes

A sync pair’s status can be changed temporarily during battle. The following is a list of status categories.
Confusion Causes a Pokémon to potentially hit itself instead of an opponent when using a move. It lasts for a certain number of Pokémon moves or until the sync pair is switched out.
Flinching Causes a Pokémon to flinch, making it unable to perform a move, and causes the move gauge to fill more slowly. It lasts for a certain amount of time or until the sync pair uses a sync move or is switched out. It will also end if the Pokémon is put to sleep or frozen.
Trapped The sync pair will no longer be able to switch out and will take damage after every action. It lasts for a few moves.
Prevent Evasion Causes moves on the target to always hit (except in certain circumstances). Lasts for a fixed amount of time or until the sync pair is switched out.
Grant Type Resistance Temporarily grants resistance to one of the following move types, reducing the damage the target takes from them: Normal, Fire, Water, Electric, Grass, Ice, Fighting, Poison, Ground, Flying, Psychic, Bug, Rock, Ghost, Dragon, Dark, Steel, and Fairy. Lasts until the sync pair is switched out.
Endurance Unless attacked with a sync move or unity attack, the sync pair will always have at least 1 HP remaining after being hit by a move that would otherwise cause them to faint. It works once or lasts until the sync pair is switched out.
Gradual Healing Recovers HP with every action. It works for a certain number of moves or until the sync pair is switched out.
Status Maintenance Prevents some status changes and all status conditions inflicted by opponents. It lasts for a certain amount of time or until the sync pair is switched out.
Sure Hit Next Causes the next move to always hit, with some exceptions. It works until a move is performed or until the sync pair is switched out.
Guaranteed Critical Hit Causes the next attack to always be a critical hit (except in certain circumstances). The attack itself may miss, however. It works until a move is performed or until the sync pair is switched out.
Ready to Counterattack

Certain moves, such as Beak Blast, will cause a sync pair to get ready to counterattack. When certain conditions are met, the move will activate. The conditions for when each move will activate differ, so please see each move’s description for details.
Sync pairs in this state are unable to use most moves. Using the move again in this state or activating a unity attack will remove it.
Defensive Posture

Certain moves, such as King’s Shield, will cause a sync pair to take up a defensive posture. Sync pairs in this state will not take damage from some moves. Depending on the move, when certain conditions are met, an additional effect will be activated. Please see each move’s description for details.
Sync pairs in this state are unable to use most moves. Using the move again in this state or activating a unity attack will remove it.
Action Order

The order in which sync pairs act.
Although battles take place in real time, moves are performed in the order chosen, as opposed to the moment they are selected. You can turn this feature on or off by going to Settings in the Poryphone menu, selecting the bottom right icon (Battle/HUD), and scrolling down to find Action Order.
Select Target
Tap an opponent’s Pokémon to use a move on them.
Opponent’s Target

A red target icon will appear underneath a Pokémon when it is being targeted by the opposing sync pairs.
All opposing sync pairs will attempt to use a move against the same target.
Things Kept After Battle
HP and move usage counts are not reset at the end of each battle in the same area. However, status conditions are removed at the end of each battle.
Weather

Battles can be affected by weather conditions.
Sunny Boosts Fire-type moves. Freezing is disabled, and the frozen status condition is removed.
Rain Boosts Water-type moves.
Hail All sync pairs in battle take damage with every action.
Sandstorm All sync pairs in battle take damage with every action.
The effect of some moves changes based on the weather. Some passive skills are only activated during certain weather conditions. When the weather has already been changed and another weather-altering effect is used, the previous weather condition is overwritten and its effects are removed.
Unity Attacks & Unity Bonus

In co-op battles, the unity gauge fills up when sync pairs from your team attack continuously. When the unity gauge hits 100%, sync pairs from your team will automatically perform a powerful unity attack.
You select which sync pairs will participate in the unity attack. The more supereffective sync pair types used, the more damage they do to opponents they are super effective against.
When three allied sync pairs continuously attack without the opponent making a move, a unity bonus is activated for a certain period of time. While the unity bonus is in effect, the damage inflicted on your team’s opponents increases and any attack performed fills the unity gauge. Performing a supereffective attack while the unity bonus is in effect increases the duration of the bonus.
Switching

In co-op play, you can switch the sync pairs participating in a battle. To switch your active sync pair with a sync pair on standby, tap that sync pair’s move window to enlarge it, then tap the Pokémon icon at the top of the window to switch. If you tap the name of a move instead of the Pokémon icon, the sync pair will use that move as soon as they switch in. Although this feature is not available in the beginning, it can be unlocked by progressing through the game.
Team Condition

When a sync pair is affected by a status condition, the name of the condition will appear at the top of that sync pair’s move window. You can check the condition of a sync pair on standby by tapping that Trainer’s icon to enlarge it. Additionally, if your active sync pair is in danger of being hit by a supereffective attack, a warning icon will appear above that Pokémon.
controllers.simple_text.tips.category5.t:
Area info can be obtained by participating in events or progressing through the main story. Once you acquire area info, that area becomes available to explore.
Depending on the area info, the length of time and number of times you can explore an area may be limited.

There are two ways of matching in co-op play.
Quick Connect: Automatically matches you with other players in the matching lobby.
Connect with Friends: Invite and play with other players. Select Invite from Friend List to choose players to invite to the matching lobby. For invited players, the area info can be accessed by selecting the Invitations button at the bottom of the Poryphone menu; they can join the co-op battle by selecting that area.
controllers.simple_text.tips.category6.t:
At the Pokémon Center, you can get items by speaking to Trainers.
Additionally, you can select certain sync pairs you’d like to see visit the Pokémon Center more often. In the Edit Team menu, select a sync pair, then tap the + icon on the left to view their detail screen. Tap the heart icon at the top left of this screen to allow that sync pair to appear more frequently.
Note: This option is not available when viewing sync pair details in the Dex.

In Missions, you can earn various rewards for fulfilling certain conditions. To see what missions you can take on, go to Missions under the Poryphone menu.
You can get a special reward for completing all of the missions within the same group.
Some missions and the rewards earned for completing them are only available for a limited period of time.
Log-in bonuses or items that exceed your inventory limit are sent here. Some items can only be claimed for a certain period of time.

When a player becomes your friend, you can invite them to the same matching lobby in co-op battles.
To make someone a friend, you must send a friend request to either a player you met in a co-op battle or a player whose ID you know, and then have them accept.
controllers.simple_text.tips.category7.t:
Use sync pair scout to befriend a random sync pair.
If you get a sync pair you already have, its sync move level will increase by 1. If the sync pair’s sync move level is already at 5, you will receive a power-up with the same ★ level as the sync pair obtained.

Using sync pair scout earns you scout points. You earn scout points each time you use sync pair scout. When you reach the maximum amount, you can choose any sync pair available to befriend during that sync pair scout period.
Once the sync pair scout period is over, the scout points collected during that time will be deleted.
You can earn coins by exchanging extra gear. Once exchanged, gear cannot be returned to you.
Exchange items and coins for other items. The quantity and type of items that can be exchanged may vary depending on the time period.
Exchange gear to earn coins, or earn them as rewards for exploring. They can be exchanged for items or used to upgrade gear.
controllers.simple_text.tips.category8.t: A team comprises the sync pairs you take with you to explore and is made up of a maximum of three sync pairs.

You can create teams for both single-player and co-op battles. You choose three sync pairs to create your team.
In a single-player battle, you control all three sync pairs on your team, and you can toggle between them as needed.
In a co-op battle, you choose the three sync pairs who will take turns battling in the center position. You cannot control the other players’ sync pairs on the left or right during battle.

You can equip your team with gear. The effects of gear extend to all of the sync pairs on the team. Some gear is only effective for certain sync pairs. In those cases, its effects only apply to the sync pairs in the team who fulfill its conditions.
You can use this feature to automatically edit your team to maximize its strength. If you select a type, the strongest team possible will be created to explore, with priority given to that type.
Multiple teams can be created and saved as preset teams. You can choose which team to use before heading out to explore. The same sync pairs and gear can be used across different teams.
A measure of your team’s strength. This number increases when you have sync pairs with higher stats and a greater number of pairs who can perform supereffective moves in the chosen area.

The categories listed below can be found in the Exchange Items menu.
\[General\] Items that can be exchanged at any time.
\[Event\] Items that can only be exchanged during a specified time period.
\[Daily\] Items that can be exchanged a specified number of times each day.
\[Monthly\] Items that can be exchanged a specified number of times each month.
There may be instances where certain categories do not contain any exchangeable items.

Single Opponent: Affects a single opponent you select.

Single Ally: Affects a single ally you select.
All Allies: Affects all allied sync pairs.
Field of Play: Affects all sync pairs in the field of play.

Field of Play (Opponents): Affects all opposing sync pairs in the field of play.

These effects can cover three areas: the allied side, the opposing side, and the entire field, thereby affecting any sync pairs in those respective areas. The following is a list of area effect types. (Some wear out after a period of time.) Damage Reduction: Reduces damage received by the target. Status Move Defense: Prevents the target from being affected by an opponent’s status move.

Chain Reduction: Shortens the duration the target’s unity bonus is available.
No Switching: Prevents sync pairs from switching.
Move Gauge Acceleration: Causes the target’s move gauge to fill more quickly.
Weather Lock: If the weather has already been changed, prevents it from being changed again.

Continuous Healing: Recovers HP with every action performed by the Pokémon. It lasts for a certain number of Pokémon moves, or until the sync pair is switched.
Condition Nullification: Prevents some status changes and all status conditions inflicted by opponents. It lasts for a certain amount of time, or until the sync pair is switched.

Critical Hit Next: Causes the next attack to always be a critical hit (except in certain circumstances). The attack itself may miss, however. It works until a move is performed, or until the sync pair is switched.

Custom Vouchers and Custom Super Vouchers can also be exchanged for special items in the shop during events.
They are not automatically converted into coins upon completion of an event, and will remain in your stock.

Battles can be affected by the following weather conditions:
Sunny Boosts Fire-type attacks. Freezing is disabled, and the frozen status condition is removed.
Rain Boosts Water-type attacks.
Hail All sync pairs on the battlefield take damage with every action.
Sandstorm All sync pairs on the battlefield take damage with every action.
The effect of some moves changes based on the weather. Some passive skills are only activated during certain weather conditions. Weather conditions return to normal and all effects are removed as time elapses. If a weather-altering effect is used while another weather condition is active, the previous weather condition is overwritten by the new one and its effects are removed.
26:
There are two ways of matching in co-op play.
Quick Connect: Automatically matches you with other players in the matching lobby.
Connect with Friends: Invite and play with other players. Select Invite from Friend List to choose players to invite to the matching lobby. For invited players, the area info for the battle can be accessed by selecting the Invitations button at the bottom of the Poryphone menu.
You can also match up using a specified party number by selecting Party Number Search on the Invitations screen or on the matching method screen for your chosen battle.
28:
In Mission Bingo, you can earn rewards by completing missions on 3×3 bingo cards. Tap the Mission Bingo icon in the Pokémon Center to see what bingo cards are currently available.
Earn extra rewards on a Mission Bingo card by completing missions that form vertical, horizontal, or diagonal lines. Complete all the missions specified on the card’s squares to achieve a blackout and earn even more rewards.
There are three types of Mission Bingo.
Difficulty-based: Bingo cards come in three difficulties: beginner, intermediate, and advanced. Missions become harder as the difficulty increases.
Weekly: Bingo card contents change every week.
Event: Bingo cards are linked to events. Complete the entire card (blackout) to take on a new set of missions.
Note: weekly Mission Bingo cards and event Mission Bingo cards are only available for a limited period of time. Rewards must be claimed during the event period from the Mission Bingo screen. They cannot be claimed after this, even if missions on these bingo cards have been completed.
30:
Learn grid skills on the sync grid to strengthen your sync pairs. Sync orbs specific to each sync pair are required to learn grid skills.
Grid Skills: Grid skills vary by sync pair. Each grid skill (one tile on the sync grid) requires a set amount of energy to activate. To activate a tile and learn a grid skill, you must first activate an adjacent tile. Some tiles have additional unlock requirements. The benefits gained by learning grid skills are not reflected on a sync pair’s detail screen or in their move descriptions. Grid skills that include a specific move name in their skill description are only effective when performing that move.
Sync Orbs: At the start of a single-player battle, you may see a Sync orb chance! message on the screen. During these battles, you can obtain a sync pair-specific sync orb when you use a sync move for the first time. Co-op sync orbs can be obtained from co-op battles. These can be exchanged for sync pair-specific sync orbs using the Sync Grid menu. The sync grid feature will unlock upon completing main story Chapter 11: Alola’s Rising Stars! Part 2.
Sync Grid Reset: Resetting will revert the sync grid to its initial state, which deactivates all tiles and returns any energy that was used. This will allow you to learn different grid skills if you so choose. The benefits gained by learning grid skills will also be removed.
32: At the start of a single-player battle, you may see a Sync orb chance! message on the screen. During these battles, you can obtain a sync pair-specific sync orb when you use a sync move for the first time. The odds of a sync orb chance occurring decrease after every appearance. However, this probability resets after the date has changed. Sync orb chance probabilities differ between single-player battles and co-op battles.
33:
During battle, the move gauge fills up over time.
Moves that use the move gauge cannot be performed until the move gauge is sufficiently full. Different moves use up a different amount of the gauge.

In co-op battles, the move gauge goes down when a sync pair on your team faints and another switches in.
34:
You can create teams for both single-player and co-op battles. You choose three sync pairs to create your team.
In a single-player battle, you control all three sync pairs on your team, and you can toggle between them as needed.
In a co-op battle, you choose the three sync pairs who will take turns battling in the center position. You cannot control the other players’ sync pairs on the left or right during battle.
Also, you cannot have 2 or more sync pairs that include Trainers with the same name in your team.
35:
Sync pairs can be temporarily affected by several different conditions and effects during battle. These effects are listed below.
Confused: The Pokémon can potentially hit itself instead of an opponent when using a move. It lasts until the Pokémon uses a certain number of moves or until the sync pair is switched out.
Flinching: Causes the Pokémon to flinch, making it unable to perform a move. While flinching, the move gauge fills more slowly. It lasts for a fixed amount of time, until the sync pair uses its sync move, or until it’s switched out. It will also end if the Pokémon is put to sleep or frozen.
Trapped: The affected sync pair can no longer be switched out, and the Pokémon takes damage after every action. It lasts until the Pokémon uses a certain number of moves.
No Evasion: Moves against the target always hit (except in certain circumstances). It lasts for a fixed amount of time or until the sync pair is switched out.
Type Resistance: Temporarily grants resistance to one of the following 18 move types: Normal, Fire, Water, Electric, Grass, Ice, Fighting, Poison, Ground, Flying, Psychic, Bug, Rock, Ghost, Dragon, Dark, Steel, or Fairy. The damage the target takes from moves of the specified type is reduced. It lasts until the sync pair is switched out.
Enduring: After being hit by a move that would otherwise cause them to faint, the Pokémon endures with 1 HP remaining. However, being hit by a unity attack, a sync move, or certain other moves can nullify this effect. It works once or lasts until the sync pair is switched out.
Gradual Healing: HP gradually recovers with every action performed by the Pokémon. It works until the Pokémon uses a certain number of moves or until the sync pair is switched out.
Condition Nullification: Prevents all status conditions as well as certain other conditions inflicted by opponents. It lasts for a fixed amount of time or until the sync pair is switched out.
Sure Hit Next: The next move always hits (except in certain circumstances). It works until the Pokémon uses a move or until the sync pair is switched out.
Critical Hit Next: The next attack is always a critical hit (except in certain circumstances). The attack itself may miss, however. It works until the Pokémon uses a move or until the sync pair is switched out.
